todaysEvents.title: RatOn Malware: NFC Fraud and RAT Capabilities
todaysEvents.description: RatOn Malware has been identified as a significant threat in NFC fraud, combining Remote Access Trojan (RAT) capabilities with NFC relay attacks.

todaysEvents.title: Bybit Exchange Security Breach
todaysEvents.description: Security experts are advising on essential tactics to implement following a reported security breach at the Bybit cryptocurrency exchange.

todaysEvents.title: University of Phoenix Ransomware Attack
todaysEvents.description: The Clop ransomware gang breached the University of Phoenix network, stealing data belonging to approximately 3.5 million students, staff, and suppliers.

todaysEvents.title: USDt Address Poisoning Scam Loss
todaysEvents.description: A victim lost $50 million in USDt due to an address poisoning scam, highlighting the risks associated with copy-pasting wallet addresses.

todaysEvents.title: Stealka Infostealer Malware Targeting Crypto
todaysEvents.description: Kaspersky identified a new infostealer malware named Stealka that targets over 80 crypto wallets and 100 browsers, spreading via fake game mods and pirated software.

todaysEvents.title: GitHub Zero-Day NTLM Hash Leak
todaysEvents.description: A new zero-day vulnerability (ms-photos_NTLM_Leak) has been disclosed on GitHub that allows attackers to leak NTLM hashes from browsers with a single click.

todaysEvents.title: Coinbase Account Drainage Scam
todaysEvents.description: A user reported a significant loss of 7,000 USD in cryptocurrency from their Coinbase account due to a drainage scam despite having security measures in place.

past7Days.briefing: This week witnessed a surge in high-severity cyber incidents, with threat actors aggressively targeting both individuals and organizations. Major exploits affected widely used platforms such as React and Fortinet, leading to rapid ransomware deployment and mass credential theft. Financially motivated attacks peaked with two consecutive $50 million USDT address-poisoning scams, demonstrating the sophistication and impact of social engineering in the crypto sector. Data breaches hit critical infrastructures, including the University of Phoenix (3.5M records), 700Credit, and the French Ministry of the Interior, while advanced malware campaigns like RatOn and Stealka exposed vulnerabilities in both traditional and emerging digital environments. Persistent scams and technical exploits across messaging apps, DeFi platforms, and legacy systems underline a widespread and evolving threat landscape, demanding immediate defensive action and heightened vigilance.
past7Days.trends: Key trends include a marked escalation in technical exploitation of software vulnerabilities (particularly React CVE-2025-55182 and new Fortinet flaws), with threat actors moving swiftly to weaponize zero-days for ransomware and token draining. Social engineering scams, especially address-poisoning within the crypto ecosystem, have spiked, leading to unprecedented financial losses. Data breach volume remains high, with attackers targeting both public and private sectors for mass information theft. There is a noticeable emergence of multi-functional malware targeting NFC payments, browsers, and crypto wallets. The convergence of technical exploits, social scams, and multi-vector malware points to an increasingly hostile and opportunistic threat environment. Legacy vulnerabilities (e.g., Starbucks CVE-2007-0450) continue to be leveraged, while coordinated campaigns target government, education, and manufacturing sectors.
past7Days.predictions: Expect sustained high risk from both technical and social attack vectors in the coming days. We anticipate continued exploitation of recently disclosed critical vulnerabilities (React, Fortinet, iMessage, Dropbear), with ransomware and data theft campaigns likely to proliferate. Crypto platforms and users remain prime targets for advanced scams and wallet drainers, particularly through phishing and address manipulationâ€”confidence in this trend is high. Further large-scale data breaches and sophisticated malware outbreaks (e.g., RatOn, Stealka) are probable, especially via supply chain and third-party platforms. Organizations should prioritize patching, monitor for signs of credential compromise, and strengthen anti-phishing controls. Special attention is warranted for sectors historically slow to patch (education, government, manufacturing) and for platforms exposed to legacy vulnerabilities. Overall, the threat level is expected to remain elevated, with high confidence in ongoing coordinated attacks and evolving scam techniques.
